com.versant.fund
Interface SelectBuilder

All Known Subinterfaces:
ClassHandle
public interface SelectBuilder

An intermediate type used in selecting instances of classes. The SelectBuilder Interface contains two categories of methods: "select" methods that must be called on class objects to retrieve instances of the class, and supporting "with" methods that provide additional functionality to select(). The ClassHandle Interface extends the SelectBuilder Interface.

Example Usage: 

 Predicate pred = session.newAttrInt("age").gt(18);
 ClassHandle ch = session.locateClass("Person");
 HandleEnumeration e= ch
 .withDatabase("thatDB")          // returns ClassHandle
 .withSelectOptions(SELECT_DEEP)  // returns SelectBuilder
 .withThisClassLockmode(IRLOCK)   // returns SelectBuilder
 .withInstanceLockmode(NOLOCK)    // returns SelectBuilder
 .select(pred);                   // returns HandleEnumeration

See Also:
ClassHandle, Predicate, Constants

Method Detail

withSelectLevels

SelectBuilder withSelectLevels(int levels)
For a query, sets the number of levels of handles to traverse starting from the handles found by the predicate.

  • Specify 0 to return only the found objects.
  • Specify -1 to return all objects linked directly or indirectly to the found objects.
  • Specify a positive number to indicate the number of levels of links to follow beginning from the found objects. For example, specify 1 to return found objects and objects that are direct targets of links in the objects found by the predicate. Specify 2 to also return objects that are the target of links in the first level of returned objects.

Note: API withSelectLevels should not be used with the SelectBuilder.cursorSelect(), it is only applicable to SelectBuilder.select.

Parameters:
levels - The number of levels of handles to traverse.

withSelectOptions

SelectBuilder withSelectOptions(int options)
For a query, sets evaluation and pinning options when doing the select.

Valid options are:

  • Constants.TOPIN: Pin the fetched objects in memory. To fetch objects, you must specify the Constants.FETCH_LAST option. The default is to not pin fetched objects. If you pin objects, you must later manually unpin them with Handle.unpinObject() or release them with a Session.commit(), Session.rollback(), or undosavepoint(). The default is to return handles but not bring the found objects into memory.
  • Constants.SELECT_DEEP: Evaluate target class and it's subclasses. This is the default option for queries where the from target is a class.
  • Constants.FLUSH_NONE: Do not flush the object cache before performing the query. If you perform your query over a class, the default is to flush the dirty objects of the specified target classes before the query is performed. Because queries are performed in the server process on the query database, normally you should flush the object cache so that the query evaluates and returns the latest state of each object. You cannot use both Constants.FLUSH_NONE and Constants.FLUSH_ALL.
  • Constants.FLUSH_ALL: Flush the object cache before performing the query. The default is to flush the dirty objects of the specified class and it's subclasses before performing the query. You cannot use both Constants.FLUSH_NONE and Constants.FLUSH_ALL. See the comments for Constants.FLUSH_NONE above.
  • Constants.FETCH_LAST: Fetch objects that satisfy the query. By default, objects that satisfy a query are not fetched from their database and placed in memory. If you have specified levels as non-zero, this option returns objects to the last level specified. Objects of intermediate levels are always fetched.

To invoke multiple options, combine them with the Java OR operator, "|".

Parameters:
options - The select options.

withThisClassLockmode

SelectBuilder withThisClassLockmode(int mode)
The short lock to be placed on the class object specified.

Alternatives for lock mode are:

  • Constants.WLOCK : Write lock
  • Constants.RIWLOCK : Read/intention-write lock
  • Constants.IWLOCK : Intention-write lock
  • Constants.ULOCK : Update lock
  • Constants.RLOCK : Read lock
  • Constants.IRLOCK : Intention-read lock
  • Constants.NOLOCK : No lock

The default lock used in a select is a Constants.IRLOCK.

Since this parameter applies only to class objects, to avoid unintentional side effects, you should normally only specify Constants.IRLOCK, Constants.IWLOCK, or Constants.NOLOCK. Sometimes, however, you may want to specifically set a read or write lock on a class object when performing a query. Thus, all lock options are supported.

Parameters:
mode - The lock mode to associate with the class object.

withInstanceLockmode

SelectBuilder withInstanceLockmode(int mode)
The short lock to be placed on the instances returned. Sets the instance lock mode for this query. The default instance lock mode is Constants.RLOCK. The lock to be placed on returned instances.

By definition, a select operation returns reference to the objects that satisfy your predicate. The default is to not place a lock on the selected objects themselves. If you specify a read, update, or write lock in this parameter, objects are locked by the server if they satisfy the predicate. This means that during the time of the select operation, you may encounter lock conflicts. It also means that afterwards, you are guaranteed that the objects corresponding to your returned result are consistent and will not change while you are looking at them. By comparison, if you do not specify a lock in this parameter and then use the returned references to fetch objects in a separate operation, there will be a window of time in which other users can modify or delete your selected objects. Even if you specify fetching options or a non-zero value in levels, a window of time will still exist in which your selected objects may be modified (although it will be much smaller.).

For NOLOCK the fetching and calculation of the closure will use the default lock mode of the session, which is typically a RLOCK. If you want to perform dirty reads then use the session method setDefaultLock(NOLOCK) before executing the query.

Parameters:
mode - The lock mode to associate with the instances. Alternatives for mode are:
  • Constants.WLOCK : Write lock
  • Constants.RIWLOCK : Read/intention-write lock
  • Constants.IWLOCK : Intention-write lock
  • Constants.ULOCK : Update lock
  • Constants.RLOCK : Read lock
  • Constants.IRLOCK : Intention-read lock
  • Constants.NOLOCK : No lock

select

HandleEnumeration select()
Finds all the objects of a class and returns a HandleEnumeration to iterate through the returned instances.

select

HandleEnumeration select(Predicate pred)
Finds objects of a class based on the search conditions in the predicate and returns a HandleEnumeration to iterate through the returned instances.

Parameters:
pred - The Predicate to use in the select.

cursorSelect

HandleEnumeration cursorSelect()
Finds all the objects of a class, using a database cursor.

A cursor select returns a HandleEnumeration just as a regular select does, but it creates a cursor and no objects are fetched from the database until the next batch of objects is retrieved from the HandleEnumeration. When you finish using a cursor, you can invalidate it to release it. By fetching batches of object at a time rather than all the objects at once, a cursor select reduces both lock contention on the fetched objects and memory usage. The maximum number of objects that you can fetch in a batch is 65536.

To use a cursor select, you can do the following: 

 ClassHandle cls = session.locateClass("Person");
 Predicate p = session.newAttrInt("age").gt(18);
 HandleEnumeration people = cls.cursorSelect();
 while (people.hasMoreHandles()) {
   HandleVector hv = people.nextBatch();
   HandleEnumeration he = hv.handles();
   while(he.hasMoreHandles()) {
     Handle h = he.nextHandle();
     // use Handle h
   }
 }
 people.invalidateCursor ();

Parameters:
pred - The Predicate to use in the select.

cursorSelect

HandleEnumeration cursorSelect(Predicate pred,
                               int initialFetchCount)
Find objects of a class using a database cursor, that satisfy a given set of search conditions, using the specified initial fetch count

Parameters:
pred - The Predicate to use in the select.
initialFetchCount - The number of objects to fetch in the initial select.
See Also:
